Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This Integrative Graduate Education and Research Training (IGERT) award supports the development of an interdisciplinary graduate program in polar sciences and engineering by merging expertise and facilities from Dartmouth College with the U.S. Army Cold Regions Research and Engineering Laboratory and institutions in Greenland. The purpose of this program is to train doctoral students to have an interdisciplinary view of polar systems and to understand the social and ethical implications of their research. Broader impacts include training and research focused on the components of polar systems that respond to and contribute to rapid environmental change, including the cryosphere (glacial ice, snow, and sea ice systems) and the biogeochemical linkages between plants, soils, and animals. The core curriculum includes an Introduction to Polar Systems and a second course on Sustainability Science, Policy and Ethics that will train students to frame research questions that will have relevance to Arctic residents and policy by using perspectives from western science and traditional ecological knowledge. Depending on their research interests, students will be trained during the Greenland Field Seminar in either terrestrial ecosystem or cryosphere dynamics, followed by instruction in the human dimensions of Arctic change in Nuuk, the site of the University of Greenland and the Inuit Circumpolar Council. IGERT students will receive continuing interdisciplinary training through a seminar series and other related events on polar science and policy organized with the Dickey Center Institute of Arctic Studies, a workshop on preparing grant proposals, an annual program evaluation and research symposium, cross-IGERT activities, and opportunities for specialized training at other institutions or field sites. A special effort will be made to engage with Native American students. IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Polar regions of the Arctic and Antarctica are experiencing rapid environmental change. In 2008, using the interdisciplinary framework of a National Science Foundation (NSF) Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT), the Institute of Arctic Studies at Dartmouth College developed a new curriculum that combines training in ecology and evolutionary biology, earth sciences, and engineering to focus on research that targets climate change and its impacts on northern peoples. As part of an interdisciplinary curriculum for science education, research and public outreach, we created an intensive field-based course in Greenland to examine the scientific, cultural and political issues that span the circumpolar region and which are important for solving global environmental issues.

As a result of this multidisciplinary curriculum, many Dartmouth IGERT graduate students developed independent research projects in Greenland. These projects are largely interdisciplinary and cover diverse topics including polar robotics, ice sheet and glacial dynamics, atmospheric science, climate impacts on soils, vegetation and lakes, and traditional use of plants and connections with the Greenlandic language. Dartmouth has instituted a new doctoral program in Ecology, Evolution, Ecosystems, and Society that is largely based on our NSF IGERT grant and we have established the McCulloch Environmental Change Graduate Fellowships to provide ongoing support for the kinds of dynamic students attracted to IGERT.

Dartmouth IGERT graduate students have had their research recognized by a number of notable scientific forums including the American Geophysical Union, the Geological Society of American, the Entomological Society of America, and the Inuit Studies Conference. Their scientific research has appeared in prominent journals such as Ecology; Nature; Bioscience; Quaternary Science Reviews; Arctic; and the Annals of Glaciology, as well as in general publications such as the Federation of Fly Fishers Magazine. Students are committed to sharing their work across disciplines, discussing with and learning from scientists, policy makers, local communities, and individuals working and living in the circumpolar North and Antarctica. 

Students demonstrated a commitment to sharing their research not just with the scientific community but with the general public as well. By creatively using a wide variety of communications vehicles from a website, blogs, videos and social media to posters, classroom discussions and in-person and virtual presentations, IGERT students shared their work and discussed critical issues facing communities in the circumpolar region, including Alaska, with a wide range of people. Audiences ranged from high school students to community groups to Greenlandic Radio to a forum on climate change held in a restaurant. A single YouTube video produced by a cohort of female Dartmouth IGERT students -- “Science in Greenland: It’s a Girl Thing” -- garnered almost 14,000 views and was praised by The New York Times. 

Dartmouth IGERT graduates continue to expand our knowledge and understanding of rapid environmental change through their postdoctoral appointments in universities, international research institutes, and in Washington, DC.
